definition[0]: to remove something by cutting round it
example[0]: The cancerous cells had to be cut out.
example[1]: Billy showed me the article he’d cut out of the magazine.
definition[1]: to cut a shape from a piece of paper, cloth etc
example[2]: The children were cutting out squares from the scraps of material.
definition[2]: to stop something from happening or existing
example[3]: The idea behind these forms is to cut out fraud.
example[4]: A catalytic converter will cut out 90% of carbon monoxide emissions.
definition[3]: to stop doing or eating something, especially because it might be bad for your health
example[5]: The current advice to pregnant women is to cut out alcohol.
definition[4]: to remove something from a piece of writing, especially because it might offend people
example[6]: Cut out the bit about racial prejudice.
definition[5]: used to tell someone to stop doing something because it is annoying you
example[7]: Hey, you guys, cut it out – Mom’s trying to get some sleep.
definition[6]: to stop someone from doing something or being involved in something
example[8]: The new rules will cut out 25% of people who were previously eligible to vote.
definition[7]: to have the qualities that you need for a particular job or activity
example[9]: In the end, I decided I wasn’t cut out for the army.
example[10]: Are you sure you’re really cut out to be a teacher?
definition[8]: if an engine or machine cuts out, it suddenly stops working
example[11]: The engine cut out halfway across the lake.
definition[9]: to prevent light, sound etc from reaching somewhere
example[12]: You’ll need sunglasses that will cut out harmful UV rays from the sun.
definition[10]: to prevent someone from getting something, especially your money after your death
example[13]: Em’s father decided to cut her out of his will.
